final_answer.precision_note: 3 s.f. from reported sample purity and molecular masses given in the report.

method: First take the mass of pure CaCO3: 5.00 g × 0.840 = 4.20 g. Convert to moles using n = m/Mr: n(CaCO3) = 4.20 / 100.1 = 4.20×10^-2 mol. From the reaction one mole CaCO3 produces one mole CO2, so n(CO2) = 4.20×10^-2 mol. Multiply by Mr(CO2): mass(CO2)=n×44.0 = 1.85 g.
checks: Maximum CO2 moles cannot exceed reactant CaCO3 moles, which is ~4.2×10^-2 mol.
1:1 stoichiometry means mass should be well below initial sample mass (yes 1.85 g < 4.20 g).
